thread.title: Hillary Clinton, mayor of New York City?
thread.title_full: Hillary Clinton, mayor of New York City?

title: Hillary Clinton, mayor of New York City?
text:
Hillary Clinton reportedly eyeing off a run for New York City mayor News Corp Australia, with wires, News Corp Australia Network January 7, 2017 10:43am 
CONGRESS has certified Donald Trump’s presidential victory, but a fresh report suggests Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton is eyeing off another powerful political position: mayor of New York City. 
The New York Daily News quoted an unnamed top Democrat who said Clinton did not rule out the possibility of running for the mayoralty during a private conversation. 
Incumbent Bill de Blasio - the first Democrat to occupy the role since the 1990s - has previously announced his intention to seek a second term at the November 2017 poll, but the New York Daily News report stated Clinton had not ruled out challenging de Blasio for the party’s nomination. 
Clinton represtented New York State in the US Senate from 2001 to 2009 but does not currently live in the city itself. She would need to move to contest the Democratic nomination. 
Sources who spoke to the New York Daily News said the formerly close relationship between Clinton and de Blasio had soured during the White House race, when he was slow to support her bid for the nomination. media_camera New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. Picture: Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP 
“It’d be sweet justice considering the way that de Blasio treated her (in the primary),” the paper quoted one Democratic leader as saying. 
The new report comes after the certification of Donald Trump’s victory by US Congress. 
House Democrats objected to the votes from at least 10 states, raising issues of voter suppression as well as American intelligence showing that Russia tried to sway the election in favour of Trump. In each case, their objections were denied because they didn’t have the support of any senators. 
Under federal law, if at least one senator and one House member object to the vote from any state, the House and Senate will meet separately to debate the merits of the objection. 
As the votes were announced for state after state, Democratic members of the House stood up to object. But in each case, no Democratic senator would join them, and Vice President Joe Biden cut them off. 
“There can be no debate,” Biden said repeatedly. “It is over.”
